net.sourceforge.jlevenshtein
Class ComparedStrings

java.lang.Object
  net.sourceforge.jlevenshtein.ComparedStrings
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.io.Serializable
public final class ComparedStrings
extends java.lang.Object
implements java.io.Serializable

This class offers various functions to describe the comparison process of the Levenshtein algorithm in this package. All results of this class are final and are consequently this object is immutable. To optimize possible long time storage of serialized instances this class does not remember any computation flags or operation costs that were used by the generating Levenshtein object.

This class is not compatible to the Java Beans framework since the later requires setter methods which do not make sense for this descriptive class.

Version:
0.2
Author:
Rafael W.
See Also:
Levenshtein, Serialized Form

levenshteinPath

public java.util.Map<HashPoint,java.lang.Integer> levenshteinPath(int firstWordID,
                                                                  int secondWordID)
                                                           throws java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException
Returns the optimal path of transformation

Parameters:
firstWordID - The ID of the first word
secondWordID - The ID of the second word
Returns:
A map that contains HashPoints as keys. These are (x,y) coordinates that have unique hash values for their x,y coordinates. The corresponding Integer will indicate the transformation action done at this point to yield one string out of the other. (As described by the ACTION_* constants x can be interpreted as a columns and y as a row in the Levenshtein matrix. (starting at origin (0,0))
Throws:
java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - If at least one of the ID does not exist

editTransformation

public static ComparedStrings.Transformation[] editTransformation(java.util.Map<HashPoint,java.lang.Integer> levenshteinPath)

This convenience wrapper function filters all real transformations that have to be undertaken on the first string to transform the later into the second string. Both strings have to be represented by a path that is yielded by the levenshteinPath method of an existing ComparedStrings object.

All resulting transformations are represented by ComparedStrings.Transformation objects that describe one step of the transformation. The character index of these objects is always relative to the original string length of the input path. Therefore, transformation skips may be skipped by the user while discarding all previous transformations. However, if the original strings are manipulated, it remains the user's responsibility to remember the change of any character indices. All alteration details remain in the resulting array but the construction of the Transformation objects will take additional time which is why working with the original path object is recommended for time consuming computations. Note that the number of resulting transformations is strictly smaller than the number of Levenshtein path nodes since ACTION_START and ACTION_REMAIN nodes do not trigger a real transformation and are therefore filtered out.

Parameters:
levenshteinPath - A Levenshtein path that describes the transformation of one string into another.
Returns:
An array with all real transformations to yield the second string out of the first string
Since:
jLevenshtein v0.2

resultTransformation

public static java.lang.String[] resultTransformation(java.util.Map<HashPoint,java.lang.Integer> levenshteinPath,
                                                      java.lang.String firstWord,
                                                      java.lang.String secondWord)

This convenience wrapper function filters all real transformations that have to be undertaken on the first string to transform the later into the second string. Both strings have to be represented by a path that is yielded by the levenshteinPath method of an existing ComparedStrings object.

All resulting transformations are represented by String objects that stand for one step of the transformation. Any further transformation details described by the original Levenshtein path are lost. Note that the number of transformations is strictly smaller than the number of Levenshtein path nodes since ACTION_START and ACTION_REMAIN nodes do not trigger a real transformation and are therefore filtered out.

Parameters:
levenshteinPath - The transformation path that alters one string into another
firstWord - The first word that is represented by levenshteinPath
secondWord - The second word that is represented by levenshteinPath
Returns:
An array of strings that describes all transformation steps including in their order
Since:
jLevenshtein v0.2

Returns:
The overall index

distance

public float distance()
Returns the (weighted) Levenshtein distance of the entire input

Returns:
The (weighted) Levenshtein distance (equals the Levenshtein distance for two single item inputs)
